currentProjects.title: Integrating Physical Properties in Natural World Creation
currentProjects.name: NRF Fellowship, National Research Foundation
currentProjects.description: The aim of PhysWorld is to create a realistic natural world adhering to physical principles, rather than dealing with only the realistic pixels as in traditional image, video, and 3D synthesis. Physics-based natural world creation is challenging because it requires a holistic interpretation of scenes and objects within it, including but not limited to appearance, geometry, materials, occlusion, motion, gravity, interaction, mass and sound.
objectives: To develop a system for feed-forward 3D reconstruction and decomposition from a set of sparse views.
To develop a system for feed-forward 4D reconstruction and decomposition from a monocular video.
To develop a system for natural world creation with physical interaction.

currentProjects.title: Feed-Forward 4D Scene Reconstruction from Any Monocular Video
currentProjects.name: Sony Focused Research Award
currentProjects.description: The aim of Vista4D is to obtain photorealistic 4D reconstructions of dynamic scenes from a single monocular video. To achieve this, Vista4D will develop a feed-forward neural network that, given as input a single monocular video, will output directly its 4D reconstruction
objectives: To learn a neural network which outputs a corresponding 4D reconstruction of the scene observed in the single monocular video.
To develop a system that completes the 4D scene by generating the missing parts.
To further develop the architecture by integrating explicit geometric constraints, such as depth estimation, object tracking and camera registration.

pastProjects.title: Synthesizing Photorealistic 3D Scene from Zero to One or Limited Views
pastProjects.name: MSCA Fellowship
pastProjects.description: The aim of SYN3D is to enable the effortless creation of novel view synthesis and 3D reconstruction from limited views (from 0 to 5) in a feed-forward manner. In general, such a few input views do not contain sufficient information for compressive 3D synthesis. However, our scientific hypothesis is that 3D synthesis from limited views is still possible by learning, from billion images, the capability of hallucinating unobserved parts of 3D objects/scenes, thus obtaining plausible if not faithful reconstructions.
objectives: To develop a feed-forward 3D scene synthesis model that reconstructs photorealistic 3D scenes from zero to one or limited views.
To develop a strategy for training the model on large-scale image datasets for generalizable 3D reconstruction across different scenes.
To decompose the 3D scene into semantically meaningful components, enabling better manipulation of the synthesized scenes.
